YMj0YvxgOTdiTGcpgic1Ng.text: My husband and I stopped in for dinner on our last night in Edinburgh.  We didn't have a reservation and got there around 5:30, but were able to easily get a seat.  When we left, the restaurant was nearly full, so if you are planning for dinner around 7+, you might want to get a reservation.    We decided to start with momos.  Our first experience with the dish was on a recent trip to London and we really enjoyed them.  The momos at The Khukuri were even better--they were exceptional!  We got the tandoori and the chili momos, both chicken, both delicious.  The chili were quite special--a spicy, savoury sauce--and there were plenty of fragrant peppers and onions accompanying the dish.    Our server asked if we would like to wait for our main course--I have never had anyone ask that before, but it was perfect.  It gave our stomachs time to enjoy the appetizer and settle before eating the larger dishes.  When we did get the main course, again, everything was beautiful and delicious.  We both chose Nepalese dishes that were unfamiliar to us, and I am afraid I don't recall the names, but both were quite tasty.  One thing to note, entrees don't come with rice, so be sure to order a side of rice if you want rice to accompany your dishes.    My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed our meal here, and will definitely return on our next trip to Scotland.

G9psSIQaU8-E-knx6vHw_w.text: Very good Nepalese food in a pleasant quiet place. Good service. Food generous. You can order spiciness to your preference. Many vegetarian/vegan choices. Be sure to order the coconut rice! Delicious! Full bar service.

photos.caption: Photo of The Khukuri - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Beg pakora
Photo of The Khukuri - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Daal Bhaat Tarkari (assorted veg dishes). I was hoping the sauces would be different but all the same.
Photo of The Khukuri - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Lamb curry (Namche)

Sl-2gbThmxC3Z_39Y2Eq2g.text: This restaurant has been the best food my family and I have had in the UK, and might be the best Indian food I've had anywhere! We ate dinner here - meat eaters and a vegan - all of us impressed with the food, and the service. A few nights later I ordered delivery and was amazed by the aloo tama bodi.   As a vegan, this is a must! Chana masala was delicious, too. Can't go wrong!

M4ismDpD0LXn4kzfiPSuJw.text: Excellent food, don't skip this place. Wide variety of selection and portion sizes are good. Excellent service too!

G5JFUgGPn35V527R7ySDKw.text: I went here with a large party, and the staff treated us like royalty. They brought out a number of starter dishes so we did not have to choose everything by single person (even accommodating for the vegetarians). They also have such a variety of dishes that when it came time to order for 15 people, the staff were very patient.  The food was great, served with some Nepali beer, and a variety of rices and naan. The owner even gave us (all 15) a small desert on the house because we were celebrating a birthday. They even wrote out a card!  Overall the dining experience was great and matched the food as well. I highly enjoyed it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Khukuri - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

uUcionvX-IKpMpaB0GIw2Q.text: Excellent authentic Nepalese food. Try the vegetable momo, Aloo Tama Bodi among others. Owner and staff were friendly and helpful. Wish we could get Nepalese food like this back in the US

LlDMGmNdOIb2g7MlAPHAOQ.text: Very good nepalese/indian food, and at reasonable prices. I got the mixed grill which consisted of Chicken tikka, lamb tikka, a lamb chop, sheek kebab, and a king prawn. They really mean king prawn, the thing was massive! With this they also include a vegetable curry, rice pilaf, and a yoghurt sauce. Got some Naan on the side which was very fresh. Service was great also, very friendly atmosphere.

rI04hptDoKdq5bquG94BHA.text: A wee Nepalese place that never struck me as one worth trying till my team leader got us there twice for lunch, and how glad I was for his recommendation!!!  The first time we had a l carte dishes, so I opted for the (very generous) lamb biryani, which I found only 2nd best for the variety I have tried in Edinburgh!! Some guys ordered the Nepalese beer named Khukuri  (Khukuri stands for the traditional Nepalese blade), and they were impressed of the gentle and refreshing taste it has (brewed in London).  For our second visit we tried out the excellent lunch deal 7.95 for two courses or 8.35 for three (where the third dish is either a coffee or a simple home made dessert). You have quite a decent choice for main dish, and both the naan bread and chapati were very tasty! There was also a mouth-watering starter, Sekuwa, which you definitely need to try, grilled chicken with spices and an awesome sauce!!  In both cases I had Mango Lassi, which helps balancing whatever spicy curry you will get (recommended over a beer!). The service was very good in both cases, and the prices are very reasonable!  Now I need to decide what dish to try next!!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Khukuri - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Sekuwa (starter - chicken)! Delicious!

Jz0O2Uo5gEo_9eJ7LUyaSg.text: The Khukuri is an excellent Indian restaurant which serves amazing food and has friendly, efficient service to match.  I came here with my flatmates late last year and we all thought it was great value for money considering what a good time we had.  The restaurant itself feels quaint and cosy with neatly laid out tables, relaxing decor and some of the most friendly staff you could ask for.   The menu has an extensive range of authentic Indian dishes and prides itself particularly on the quality of its meat.  I went for the lamb Rogan Josh which had tender chunks of lamb in an aromatic and flavoursome sauce.  They also serve big, filling portions of rice to go with their main dishes. We spent less than a tenner each when the final bill came which we all thought was excellent deal.  This place is definitely worth a look!

photos.caption: Photo of The Khukuri - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

BfZyF3eC01CzR32L_goWyA.text: If I'd not eaten out again in town the night after I was here this past weekend I'd have thought I was maybe out of touch with prices through making use of deals and vouchers over the past few months. At 24 per head for only main courses (3 curries, 3 rice and one naan) and beers this was more than I'd paid in quite a while but it does seem to be out of the ordinary thankfully, at least when you're missing out both a starter and a dessert.   No complaints about the food itself, or for that matter the service although the waiting staff did seem to have the odd problem understanding my German guests (both of whom have an excellent command of English) so they're maybe used solely to Edinburgh accents. I will not though be back here anytime soon.

Cvtn78NK8BRJRsXPQe26aQ.text: Great variety. Great folks. Decent prices. Excellent alternative to standard Indian. Also, try the Everest beer - nice clean taste.

nW9VU6Nr6Nm3Qf2reDsWUw.text: Oh wow!  I can't believe no one else has reviewed this place yet!  I've been here twice and it was amazing both times.  R and his family have been going here for a while now and love the place.  We'll be back in Edinburgh in a week and there's a chance we might be having dinner here one night so I'll be writing an updated review soon since it's been two years since I've been here.  I'm hoping it's as good as I remember.  If memory serves, they make the most amazing Chicken Korma...wow my mouth is watering already!

4hVsb3eqIBX0FfqizYqdBg.text: The food is good and the staff True Nepalese, friendly and soft spoken. This brings me back to my time in Kathmandu

VfGLOcuZ_CTFrkqREtmPZw.text: The best Asian restaurant in Edinburgh, it doesn't look much from the outside but wait until you have tried the food. The Khukuri is a Nepalese restaurant, I'm not a food expert but I just find their food more enjoyable than Indian food, I think its got more flavour.  When we moved to Edinburgh about 10 years ago we started taking vistors to the Khukuri and everyone of them said it was the best Asian restaurant that they had eat in and on return visits to Edinburgh our friends always requested a return visit to the Khukuri There is an extensive menu, the food is great, the service is superb, I just can't find any faults in the place, its a little gem. But don't tell to many people or it will be even harder to get a table.

_sPgVUuNuq0JPeRGsaIXKg.text: This Nepalese restaurant was the best place we visited on our trip to Edinburgh. Well that might be a sligh exaggeration but only slight. We found it by the simple expedient of getting off the bus at a spot that had a lot of restaurants and reading the menu cards outside them till we found on that looked interesting. This one seemed both not too expensive and good. There was a single article outside about the awards the chef had won and though every Asian restaurant seems to have signs like this outside, this one seemed to be modest about it's achievements and we thought we'd give it a try. Thank heavens we did. The service was impeccable with the attentive Nepalese waiter guiding us through the menu and recommending what turned out to be delicious dishes. The food was truly superb and I would have given the chef an award on the spot if I had one handy :). The atmosphere is nice but nothing special but for food like this, I'd sit on the street and eat it! Do visit.

jtnPLmOEsIhFGyk-NO2ejw.text: A gem in an unassuming external decor. If you like "indian" (it's actually Nepalese) food without the oil and food colourings but with great taste and flavour, this is IT! The chef used to work with medicinal herbs in Nepal (25 yrs ago he tells me) and the curries shows. The ingredients feels fresh and have plenty of flavour without being empowering or oily. There is a huge selection of curries and the service was above average. Try it and you won't be disappointed.
